Miss Daniel then introduced Mr. Lawrence Creshkoff, assistant director of pro¬
grams for WGBH-TV, and former NAEB-recommended Fulbright scholar in Paris. Mr.
Creshkoff spoke as follows:
nThank you, Miss Daniel, and thank you all. I'm not going to speak much tonight
as I have some pictures and we've been thinking in terms of audio-visual education.
We all know one picture is worth 1000 words.
’’Last year I was privileged by the opportunity presented to NAEB to spend 10
months in France with the French Broadcasting System. For nine months, I had
almost no responsibilities and almost everyone I talked to would listen at least
sympathetically for a while. One of the most interesting parts of the stay was the
opportunity to observe the European TV Network in action. In 1952, for one week
the French and English Broadcasting Systems exchanged programs. Then, for the
Coronation in 1953 the TV programs were sent to France, Belgium, Holland, West
Germany, and Berlin. (Slides of maps, etc. illustrate these remarks.) The number
of miles involved in transmitting was not much greater than from New York to the
middle of Ohio, but with the problems of frontiers, language barriers and a different
set of standards in the various countries, there were many problems. Last year
